channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Zelenskyy wants Ukrainians to have a say in the talks to end the war with Russia
item.description: Ukraine's president says he will look into changing the constitution to hold wartime elections or a referendum on ceding territory to Russia amid ongoing peace talks to end the war.
item.content:encoded: Ukraine's president says he will look into changing the constitution to hold wartime elections or a referendum on ceding territory to Russia amid ongoing peace talks to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Kakissis

item.title: Former National Security Council official on the current state of the war in Ukraine
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with retired Army Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman about the current state of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with retired Army Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman about the current state of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Dueling health care plans fail in the Senate as ACA premium deadline approaches
item.description: Competing health care plans failed to meet the 60-vote threshold in the Senate Thursday. With federal ACA subsidies set to expire, health insurance costs are expected to surge in the new year.
item.content:encoded: Competing health care plans failed to meet the 60-vote threshold in the Senate Thursday. With federal ACA subsidies set to expire, health insurance costs are expected to surge in the new year.
item.dc:creator: Saige Miller

item.title: Exposure to extreme heat can lead to developmental setbacks in kids, research says
item.description: New research suggests that for some children exposure to extreme heat could lead to setbacks on key developmental milestones.
item.content:encoded: New research suggests that for some children exposure to extreme heat could lead to setbacks on key developmental milestones.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: U.S. military members fear personal legal blowback tied to boat strikes
item.description: Staff officers and at least one drone pilot have sought advice from outside groups over legal concerns about their own involvement — or potential involvement — in the strikes against suspected drug boats.
item.content:encoded:
Staff officers and at least one drone pilot have sought advice from outside groups over legal concerns about their own involvement — or potential involvement — in the strikes against suspected drug boats.

(Image credit: Evan Vucci)
item.dc:creator: Ryan Lucas

item.title: Trump struggles to find his economic messaging amid voter skepticism
item.description: Nearly a year into his second term, President Trump is facing growing skepticism as Americans feel persistent cost-of-living pressures despite his efforts to defend the strength of the economy.
item.content:encoded:
Nearly a year into his second term, President Trump is facing growing skepticism as Americans feel persistent cost-of-living pressures despite his efforts to defend the strength of the economy.

(Image credit: Alex Wong)
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kurtzleben

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: A look at the current state of the war in Ukraine, the Salvadoran national who became a symbol of Trump's deportation efforts released from ICE custody, Indiana lawmakers reject redistricting plan.
item.content:encoded: A look at the current state of the war in Ukraine, the Salvadoran national who became a symbol of Trump's deportation efforts released from ICE custody, Indiana lawmakers reject redistricting plan.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: Why the U.S. struggles with passenger service despite having the most rail lines
item.description: The U.S. has the most railroad tracks of any country, but we're not known for our passenger trains. A look at America's rail system and the trouble with passenger trains.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. has the most railroad tracks of any country, but we're not known for our passenger trains. A look at America's rail system and the trouble with passenger trains.
item.dc:creator: Stephan Bisaha

item.title: Testosterone levels have declined in men. Here's what the FDA wants to do about it
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with FDA Commissioner Martin Makary about the decline in testosterone in men in the U.S. and what his agency wants to do about it.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with FDA Commissioner Martin Makary about the decline in testosterone in men in the U.S. and what his agency wants to do about it.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: New study reveals effects of COVID school closures on students' mental health
item.description: A new study is providing hard data about just how bad school closures during the COVID-19 pandemic were for children's mental health.
item.content:encoded: A new study is providing hard data about just how bad school closures during the COVID-19 pandemic were for children's mental health.
item.dc:creator: Hosts
